greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: If 2n = 2^e1 + 2^e2 + ... + 2^ek [e1 .. ek distinct], then a(n) = A002110(e1) * A002110(e2) * ... * A002110(ek).
comment: a(n) = Product of distinct primorials larger than one, obtained as Product_{i} A002110(1+i), where i ranges over the zero-based positions of the 1-bits present in the binary representation of n.
This sequence can be represented as a binary tree. Each child to the left is obtained as A283980(k), and each child to the right is obtained as 2*A283980(k), when their parent contains k:
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..4095
Index entries for sequences related to binary expansion of n
Index entries for sequences related to primorial numbers
formula: Other identities. For all n >= 0 (or for n >= 1):
A276150(a(n)) = A324342(n). [subsequences in the latter are converging towards this sequence]
G.f.: Product_{k>=0} (1 + prime(k + 1)# * x^(2^k)), where prime()# = A002110. - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Aug 19 2019
mathematica: Table[Times @@ Map[#1^#2 & @@ # &, FactorInteger[#] /. {p_, e_} /; e == 1 :> {Times @@ Prime@ Range@ PrimePi@ p, e}] &[Times @@ Prime@ Flatten@ Position[#, 1] &@ Reverse@ IntegerDigits[n, 2]], {n, 0, 43}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Mar 18 2017 *)
program: (PARI) A283477(n) = prod(i=0,exponent(n),if(bittest(n,i),vecprod(primes(1+i)),1)) \\ Edited by _M. F. Hasler_, Nov 11 2019
;; Recursive "binary tree" implementation, using memoization-macro definec:
from sympy import prime, primerange, factorint
def P(n): return reduce(mul, [i for i in primerange(2, n + 1)])
return 1 if n==1 else reduce(mul, [P(i)**f[i] for i in f])
def a019565(n): return reduce(mul, (prime(i+1) for i, v in enumerate(bin(n)[:1:-1]) if v == '1')) if n > 0 else 1 # after _Chai Wah Wu_
print([a(n) for n in range(101)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, Jun 22 2017
xref: Cf. A129912 (same terms, but sorted into ascending order).
Cf. A005940, A052330, A322827, A323505 for other similar trees.
